_childDocuments_.content: For release on delivery 1:45 p.m. EDT March 23, 2012 Opening Remarks by Ben S. Bernanke Chairman Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System at “Central Banking: Before, During, and After the Crisis” A Conference Sponsored by the Federal Reserve Board and the International Journal of Central Banking Washington, D.C. March 23, 2012

_childDocuments_.content_extracted: Distinguished guests, colleagues, and friends:  It is my privilege to welcome you   to this conference on “Central Banking:  Before, During, and After the Crisis,” which is   jointly sponsored by the Federal Reserve Board and the International Journal of Central   Banking. 1   We hope that the conference will foster discussion among policymakers and   researchers about the evolving challenges facing central banks around the world.  To help   get that discussion started, the conference will feature original research on monetary   policy, macroprudential regulation, and the provision of liquidity, topics that are   obviously highly relevant to the public policy missions of the Federal Reserve and other   central banks.  The proceedings from this conference will be published in a special issue   of the journal and disseminated to researchers in central banks and academic institutions   worldwide.   Needless to say, the events of the past few years pose serious challenges to the   conventional, pre-crisis views and approaches of central banks and other financial   supervisors.  The crisis, the recession it sparked, and the subsequent slow recovery,   especially in the advanced economies, have demonstrated that we have much to learn   about the workings and vulnerabilities of our modern, globalized financial system and its   interactions with the broader economy.  In responding to these stressful financial and   economic developments, the Federal Reserve and other central banks have had to deploy   a variety of new tools and approaches to carry out their responsibilities regarding   monetary policy and the provision of liquidity, tools about which we still have more to   learn.  Finally, in the wake of the crisis, the Federal Reserve and other regulatory   agencies have been charged with challenging new responsibilities in the area of                                                     1  More information about the conference, held at the Madison Hotel, Washington, D.C., March 23-24,   2012, is available on the Board’s website at www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/conferences/central-  banking-conference-before-during-after-crisis-about.htm.

_childDocuments_.content: Distinguished guests, colleagues, and friends: It is my privilege to welcome you to this conference on “Central Banking: Before, During, and After the Crisis,” which is jointly sponsored by the Federal Reserve Board and the International Journal of Central Banking.’ We hope that the conference will foster discussion among policymakers and researchers about the evolving challenges facing central banks around the world. To help get that discussion started, the conference will feature original research on monetary policy, macroprudential regulation, and the provision of liquidity, topics that are obviously highly relevant to the public policy missions of the Federal Reserve and other central banks. The proceedings from this conference will be published in a special issue of the journal and disseminated to researchers in central banks and academic institutions worldwide. Needless to say, the events of the past few years pose serious challenges to the conventional, pre-crisis views and approaches of central banks and other financial supervisors. The crisis, the recession it sparked, and the subsequent slow recovery, especially in the advanced economies, have demonstrated that we have much to learn about the workings and vulnerabilities of our modern, globalized financial system and its interactions with the broader economy. In responding to these stressful financial and economic developments, the Federal Reserve and other central banks have had to deploy a variety of new tools and approaches to carry out their responsibilities regarding monetary policy and the provision of liquidity, tools about which we still have more to learn. Finally, in the wake of the crisis, the Federal Reserve and other regulatory agencies have been charged with challenging new responsibilities in the area of  ' More information about the conference, held at the Madison Hotel, Washington, D.C., March 23-24, 2012, is available on the Board’s website at www. federalreserve.gov/newsevents/conferences/central- banking-conference-before-during-after-crisis-about.htm.

_childDocuments_.content_extracted: - 2 -    macroprudential supervision, with the objective of promoting financial stability and   reducing the likelihood and the costs of a future financial crisis.  Although much progress   has been made, we are still at an early stage in understanding how best to meet these new   macroprudential responsibilities.   All of these developments have spurred a great deal of research within central   banks, in academia, and elsewhere.  This outpouring of research will help shape future   central bank doctrine and policy approaches and, most importantly, should help central   banks better carry out their mission to promote the public welfare.  The papers at this   conference make a variety of welcome contributions to this endeavor.  Two contributions   consider the implications of recent events for the conduct of monetary policy, both   conventional and unconventional. 2   Another paper addresses the relationship between   monetary aggregates and financial stability. 3   And several papers investigate issues in the   field of regulation and macroprudential supervision, including the design of an integrated   framework for regulation, a proposal for dealing with systemically important resolution   issues in the repurchase agreement markets, and a review of the progress to date in   reengineering the financial system. 4                                                        2  See Mark Gertler and Peter Karadi (2012), “QE 1 vs. 2 vs. 3 . . .  A Framework for Analyzing Large-  Scale Asset Purchases as a Monetary Policy Tool,” March,   www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/conferences/GertlerKaradi.pdf; and Athanasios Orphanides and   Volker Wieland (2012), “Complexity and Monetary Policy,” forthcoming.  3  See Hyun Jeong Kim, Hyun Song Shin, and Jaeho Yun (2012), “Monetary Aggregates and the Central   Bank’s Financial Stability Mandate,” March 6,   www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/conferences/KimShinYun.pdf.  4  See Charles A. E. Goodhart, Anil K. Kashyap, Dimitrious P. Tsomocos, and Alex P. Vardoulakis (2012),   “An Integrated Framework for Multiple Financial Regulations,” March,   www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/conferences/GoodhartKashyapTsomocosVardoulakis.pdf; Viral V.   Acharya and Sabri Oncu (2012), “A Proposal for the Resolution of Systemically Important Assets and   Liabilities:  The Case of the Repo Market,” March 23,   www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/conferences/AcharyaOncu.pdf; and Darrell Duffie (2012),   “Replumbing Our Financial System:  Uneven Progress,” March 17,   www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/conferences/Duffie.pdf.

_childDocuments_.content: -2- macroprudential supervision, with the objective of promoting financial stability and reducing the likelihood and the costs of a future financial crisis. Although much progress has been made, we are still at an early stage in understanding how best to meet these new macroprudential responsibilities. All of these developments have spurred a great deal of research within central banks, in academia, and elsewhere. This outpouring of research will help shape future central bank doctrine and policy approaches and, most importantly, should help central banks better carry out their mission to promote the public welfare. The papers at this conference make a variety of welcome contributions to this endeavor. Two contributions consider the implications of recent events for the conduct of monetary policy, both conventional and unconventional.” Another paper addresses the relationship between monetary aggregates and financial stability.? And several papers investigate issues in the field of regulation and macroprudential supervision, including the design of an integrated framework for regulation, a proposal for dealing with systemically important resolution issues in the repurchase agreement markets, and a review of the progress to date in . . . . 4 reengineering the financial system.  * See Mark Gertler and Peter Karadi (2012), “QE 1 vs. 2 vs.3... A Framework for Analyzing Large- Scale Asset Purchases as a Monetary Policy Tool,” March, www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/conferences/GertlerKaradi.pdf; and Athanasios Orphanides and Volker Wieland (2012), “Complexity and Monetary Policy,” forthcoming. * See Hyun Jeong Kim, Hyun Song Shin, and Jaeho Yun (2012), “Monetary Aggregates and the Central Bank’s Financial Stability Mandate,” March 6, www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/conferences/KimShinY un.pdf. * See Charles A. E. Goodhart, Anil K. Kashyap, Dimitrious P. Tsomocos, and Alex P. Vardoulakis (2012), “An Integrated Framework for Multiple Financial Regulations,” March, www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/conferences/GoodhartKashyapTsomocosVardoulakis.pdf; Viral V. Acharya and Sabri Oncu (2012), “A Proposal for the Resolution of Systemically Important Assets and Liabilities: The Case of the Repo Market,” March 23, www. federalreserve.gov/newsevents/conferences/AcharyaOncu.pdf; and Darrell Duffie (2012), “Replumbing Our Financial System: Uneven Progress,” March 17, www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/conferences/Duffie.pdf.
